resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Southern Historical Collection</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Tillett, Charles Walter, 1888-1952.</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Charles Walter Tillett Papers, <unitdate>1853-1954</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <unitid>4438</unitid>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>About 2,000 items (11.0 linear feet) </extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>Charles Walter Tillett (1888-1952) was a prominent Charlotte, N.C., lawyer, supporter of the United Nations, and University of North Carolina trustee. The collection includes correspondence, speeches, writings, and research materials of Tillett. Over half of the materials are documents Tillett used in researching his speeches and articles. Many items relate to the United Nations and international law. Most of Tillett's speeches and articles deal with international concerns, although some pertain to local Charlotte and Mecklenburg County, state, and national Democratic Party politics; legal matters; and civic organizations. Correspondence, which dates from 1907 to 1952, largely concerns legal matters; fund-raising campaigns for various organizations; Tillett's work for the American Bar Association's section on International and Comparative Law; and his involvement in various activities at the University of North Carolina, including his service on the Board of Trustees. There are also materials relating to various aspects of his legal career and a few relating to his personal life. Among Tillett's correspondents were Josephus Daniels, John C. B. Ehringhaus, Edward Kidder Graham, Frank Porter Graham, and Tillett's wife Gladys Avery Tillett. Also included are some materials relating to Tillett's parents.</abstract>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language>English.</language>
                  </langmaterial>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Charles Walter Tillett Papers, 1853-1954
resource.abstract: Charles Walter Tillett (1888-1952) was a prominent Charlotte, N.C., lawyer, supporter of the United Nations, and University of North Carolina trustee. The collection includes correspondence, speeches, writings, and research materials of Tillett. Over half of the materials are documents Tillett used in researching his speeches and articles. Many items relate to the United Nations and international law. Most of Tillett's speeches and articles deal with international concerns, although some pertain to local Charlotte and Mecklenburg County, state, and national Democratic Party politics; legal matters; and civic organizations. Correspondence, which dates from 1907 to 1952, largely concerns legal matters; fund-raising campaigns for various organizations; Tillett's work for the American Bar Association's section on International and Comparative Law; and his involvement in various activities at the University of North Carolina, including his service on the Board of Trustees. There are also materials relating to various aspects of his legal career and a few relating to his personal life. Among Tillett's correspondents were Josephus Daniels, John C. B. Ehringhaus, Edward Kidder Graham, Frank Porter Graham, and Tillett's wife Gladys Avery Tillett. Also included are some materials relating to Tillett's parents.

nameEntries.original: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Library. Southern Historical Collection

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Wyman, Louis C. (Louis Crosby), 1917-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1899-1972.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence, mss., personal, professional, and financial papers of Grenville Clark, lawyer, of Dublin, N.H. and New York, N.Y. Collection includes material related to his association with the "Plattsburgh movement" and officer training before World War I, the National Economy League and the drafting of the Economy Act of 1933, the institution of the selective service system in 1940, the Dublin conferences of 1945 and 1965 on world government, and Harvard Corporation and the revitalization of Harvard Divinity School. Also includes material related to his participation in other matters of public service and his concern about civil rights. Includes research material for his book with Louis B. Sohn, World peace through world law (published as: World peace through world law. -- Cambridge, Mass. : Harvard University Press, c1958). Many organizations with which Clark was associated are represented in the collection, including the American Bar Association Committee on the Bill of Rights, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the Citizens' Committee for Universal Military Training, the Ford Foundation, and the National Economy League. Correspondents include Fanny Dwight Clark, Dean Acheson, Clement Atlee, Sir Winston Churchill, John Foster Dulles, Felix Frankfurter, Robert Frost, and John F. Kennedy. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>New Hampshire Newsp Project</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1899-1972.
resource.abstract: Correspondence, mss., personal, professional, and financial papers of Grenville Clark, lawyer, of Dublin, N.H. and New York, N.Y. Collection includes material related to his association with the "Plattsburgh movement" and officer training before World War I, the National Economy League and the drafting of the Economy Act of 1933, the institution of the selective service system in 1940, the Dublin conferences of 1945 and 1965 on world government, and Harvard Corporation and the revitalization of Harvard Divinity School. Also includes material related to his participation in other matters of public service and his concern about civil rights. Includes research material for his book with Louis B. Sohn, World peace through world law (published as: World peace through world law. -- Cambridge, Mass. : Harvard University Press, c1958). Many organizations with which Clark was associated are represented in the collection, including the American Bar Association Committee on the Bill of Rights, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, the Citizens' Committee for Universal Military Training, the Ford Foundation, and the National Economy League. Correspondents include Fanny Dwight Clark, Dean Acheson, Clement Atlee, Sir Winston Churchill, John Foster Dulles, Felix Frankfurter, Robert Frost, and John F. Kennedy.

resource.title: Morris S. Lazaron papers
resource.abstract: The Morris S. Lazaron papers describe the career of Morris S. Lazaron, rabbi, community leader, and an important personality in 20th century American Reform Judaism. The collection spans the years 1851-1979 and includes correspondence, sermons, manuscripts, published articles, congregational papers, scrapbooks, and personal items.
resource.extent: 18.4 linear feet; 46 Hollinger boxes; one oversize box

nameEntries.original: The Jacob Rader Marcus Center of the American Jewish Archives

resource.title: Henry Lee Shattuck papers, 1870-1971
resource.abstract: This collection consists of the personal and professional papers of attorney, philanthropist, and public official Henry Lee Shattuck, including papers related to Boston and Massachusetts government, as well as national affairs.

resourceRelations.content: Shattuck, Henry Lee, 1879-1971. Henry Lee Shattuck papers, 1897-1971.

resource.title: Learned Hand papers, 1840-1961
resource.abstract: Materials relating to Hand's private and public life, his activities as an alumnus of Harvard University, his friendship with Felix Frankfurter, and to the Hand family. Includes material on the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, New York City; information on the Progressive movement (1909-1914) and the beginnings of the New Republic and its early staff; and transcripts of oral-history interviews conducted by Gerald Gunther of Stanford Law School and others, of Judge Hand, his family and associates.
resource.extent: 235 MSS boxes; 18 Paige boxes; 116.6 linear ft.

nameEntries.original: Harvard Law School Library, Harvard University.

resource.title: Roscoe Pound papers
resource.abstract: Includes material pertaining to Pound's participation in the Boston and Cleveland crime surveys (1920's), as a member of the National Commission on Law Observance and Enforcement or Wickersham Commission (1929-1931), as a member of the American Bar Association and with various Masonic chapters, and as advisor to the Ministry of Justice in Nanking, China (1940's). Also two typed, bound journals recounting camping trips in West Virginia and to Civil War battlefields (1898, 1912-1917).

nameEntries.original: Harvard Law School Library, Harvard University.
